title: Luke Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Luke chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Luke Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Luke Chapter 17.

questions.question: According to Luke 17:2, what would be better than offending one of the little ones?
options: To have a millstone hanged about his neck and be cast into the sea
To be banished from the community
questions.correctAnswer: To have a millstone hanged about his neck and be cast into the sea
questions.explanation: Luke 17:2 says it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and he cast into the sea, than that he should offend one of these little ones.

questions.question: In Luke 17:3, what are you instructed to do if your brother trespasses against you and then repents?
questions.correctAnswer: Forgive him
questions.explanation: Luke 17:3 instructs to rebuke the brother who trespasses and if he repents, then forgive him.

questions.question: How many times a day does Luke 17:4 say you should forgive a brother who repents?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven times
questions.explanation: Luke 17:4 says if he trespass against thee seven times in a day, and seven times in a day turn again to thee, saying, I repent; thou shalt forgive him.

questions.question: What did the apostles ask the Lord to do in Luke 17:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Increase our faith
questions.explanation: Luke 17:5 records the apostles saying unto the Lord, Increase our faith.

questions.question: According to Luke 17:6, what could faith as small as a mustard seed do?
options: Command a sycamine tree to be plucked up and planted in the sea
questions.correctAnswer: Command a sycamine tree to be plucked up and planted in the sea
questions.explanation: Luke 17:6 describes that with faith as a grain of mustard seed, one might say to a sycamine tree, 'Be thou plucked up by the root, and be thou planted in the sea,' and it would obey.

questions.question: In Luke 17:10, how should servants regard their work after doing all that is commanded?
options: As unprofitable servants doing their duty
questions.correctAnswer: As unprofitable servants doing their duty
questions.explanation: Luke 17:10 says when servants have done all commanded, they should say, 'We are unprofitable servants: we have done that which was our duty to do.'

questions.question: How many lepers met Jesus in the village according to Luke 17:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Ten
questions.explanation: Luke 17:12 states that ten men that were lepers met Jesus as he entered into a certain village.

questions.question: What did the lepers say to Jesus in Luke 17:13?
options: Jesus, Master, have mercy on us
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus, Master, have mercy on us
questions.explanation: Luke 17:13 records the lepers lifting up their voices saying, 'Jesus, Master, have mercy on us.'

questions.question: According to Luke 17:14, what happened to the lepers as they went to show themselves to the priests?
questions.correctAnswer: They were cleansed
questions.explanation: Luke 17:14 says as the lepers went to show themselves unto the priests, they were cleansed.

questions.question: Who was the one leper that returned to glorify God, as mentioned in Luke 17:16?
questions.correctAnswer: A Samaritan
questions.explanation: Luke 17:16 identifies the one who returned and gave thanks as a Samaritan.

questions.question: True or False: Luke 17:20 says the kingdom of God comes with observation.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 17:20 states the kingdom of God cometh not with observation.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus compares the coming of the Son of man to lightning shining across the sky in Luke 17:24.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 17:24 says the Son of man will be like lightning shining from one part under heaven to the other part.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 17:32, Jesus instructs to forget about Lot's wife.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 17:32 says, 'Remember Lot's wife,' instructing to recall her story.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Luke 17:33 says, 'Whosoever shall seek to save his life shall _____ it; and whosoever shall lose his life shall preserve it.'
questions.correctAnswer: lose
questions.explanation: Luke 17:33 says, 'Whosoever shall seek to save his life shall lose it; and whosoever shall lose his life shall preserve it.'

questions.question: According to Luke 17:37, where will the eagles be gathered?
questions.correctAnswer: Wherever the body is
questions.explanation: Luke 17:37 says, 'Wheresoever the body is, thither will the eagles be gathered together.'

medium.title: Luke Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Luke Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer has been repeatedly hurt by another brother. Based on Luke 17, how should they respond to encourage forgiveness?
options: Rebuke the brother and forgive him if he repents, even if it happens seven times a day
Ignore the offense and never speak to the brother again
Hold a grudge to protect themselves from further hurt
Seek revenge to teach the brother a lesson
questions.correctAnswer: Rebuke the brother and forgive him if he repents, even if it happens seven times a day
questions.explanation: Luke 17:3-4 teaches that if a brother trespasses, we should rebuke him and forgive him if he repents, even if it happens multiple times a day. This emphasizes forgiveness and reconciliation.

questions.question: How does Luke 17 describe the relationship between faith and accomplishing difficult tasks?
options: Faith as small as a mustard seed can command great things to obey
Faith must be large and visible to be effective
Faith requires many signs to prove itself
Faith is only useful for personal comfort
questions.correctAnswer: Faith as small as a mustard seed can command great things to obey
questions.explanation: In Luke 17:6, Jesus says that if we have faith as a grain of mustard seed, we can command a sycamine tree to be uprooted and it will obey. This teaches the power of even small faith.

questions.question: What does Jesus teach about the attitude of a servant who has done his duty?
options: The servant is unprofitable and only does his duty
The servant deserves a special reward
The servant should expect public praise
The servant can rest without further work
questions.correctAnswer: The servant is unprofitable and only does his duty
questions.explanation: Luke 17:10 explains that when servants have done all commanded, they should say they are unprofitable and have only done their duty, emphasizing humility and faithful service.

questions.question: What lesson about gratitude and praise does the healing of the ten lepers in Luke 17 teach us?
options: Only one returned to give thanks, highlighting the importance of gratitude
The priests should be thanked instead of Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Only one returned to give thanks, highlighting the importance of gratitude
questions.explanation: Luke 17:15-17 shows that only one of the ten healed lepers returned to glorify God and thank Jesus, teaching the vital Christian virtue of gratitude.

questions.question: How does Luke 17 teach us to understand the coming of the kingdom of God?
options: The kingdom of God comes without observation and is within you
It will come with visible signs and public announcements
It is only a future event with no present reality
It can be located by going to specific places
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom of God comes without observation and is within you
questions.explanation: Luke 17:20-21 explains that the kingdom of God does not come with observable signs but is within believers, emphasizing a spiritual, inward reality.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give about seeking to save your life according to Luke 17?
options: Whoever seeks to save their life will lose it, but whoever loses their life will preserve it
Saving your life is the highest priority
Life should be preserved at all costs
Self-preservation is a sign of strong faith
questions.correctAnswer: Whoever seeks to save their life will lose it, but whoever loses their life will preserve it
questions.explanation: Luke 17:33 teaches the paradox that those who cling to life selfishly will lose it, while those who sacrifice for God’s sake will preserve it, highlighting humility and surrender.

questions.question: When Jesus spoke about the days of Noah and Lot, what practical lesson about daily living did He emphasize?
options: People were carrying on their normal lives unaware of coming judgment
People were focused on repentance and warning others
They lived holy and separated lives
They were actively preparing for the flood
questions.correctAnswer: People were carrying on their normal lives unaware of coming judgment
questions.explanation: Luke 17:26-29 describes people eating, drinking, marrying, and buying/selling as usual before sudden judgment, warning believers to live with spiritual alertness.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 17, Jesus said it would be easy for the disciples to recognize the exact day of the Son of Man’s coming.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 17:22-23 teaches that the days of the Son of Man’s coming will be unexpected and disciples should not follow false reports, indicating it will not be easy to recognize the exact day.

questions.question: According to Luke 17, what should a servant expect after doing what is commanded?
options: No special thanks, because it is their duty
questions.correctAnswer: No special thanks, because it is their duty
questions.explanation: Luke 17:9-10 explains that a servant is not thanked for simply doing his duty, teaching humility and faithful obedience without seeking reward.

questions.question: What practical counsel does Jesus give about possessions during the coming of the Son of Man?
options: Do not go back to retrieve your possessions when the time comes
Gather all your possessions before the event
Store possessions in a safe place
questions.correctAnswer: Do not go back to retrieve your possessions when the time comes
questions.explanation: Luke 17:31 instructs those on the housetop or in the field not to return to take their possessions, emphasizing readiness and detachment from material things.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus said, "The kingdom of God is ______ you."
questions.correctAnswer: within
questions.explanation: Luke 17:21 states that the kingdom of God is within you, teaching believers that God's reign is an inward spiritual reality.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the fate of those who cling to their life versus those who lose it for His sake?
options: Those who cling to life lose it; those who lose it preserve it
Clinging to life leads to eternal life
Preserving life is the ultimate goal
questions.correctAnswer: Those who cling to life lose it; those who lose it preserve it
questions.explanation: Luke 17:33 explains the paradox of life and death in the kingdom: surrendering life for God's sake leads to true preservation.

questions.question: How does Luke 17 illustrate the importance of faith with the image of the mustard seed?
options: Even small faith can accomplish great things if exercised
Faith must be large to move mountains
questions.correctAnswer: Even small faith can accomplish great things if exercised
questions.explanation: Luke 17:6 shows that faith as small as a mustard seed can command a tree to move, emphasizing the power and potential of genuine faith.

questions.question: What does the example of the healed Samaritan leper teach about evangelism and gratitude?
options: True gratitude leads to glorifying God and acknowledging faith
Only the majority respond in faith
Evangelism is not necessary after healing
questions.correctAnswer: True gratitude leads to glorifying God and acknowledging faith
questions.explanation: Luke 17:15-19 shows the one leper who returned to thank Jesus was commended for his faith, illustrating the connection between gratitude, faith, and witnessing.

questions.question: True or False: According to Luke 17, followers of Christ should expect the Son of Man to be rejected and suffer before His revelation.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Luke 17:25 states that the Son of Man must suffer many things and be rejected by this generation before His glory is revealed.

hard.title: Luke Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Luke Chapter 17.

questions.question: In Luke 17:2, Jesus says it would be better for a man to have what tied around his neck than to cause one of the little ones to sin?
questions.correctAnswer: A millstone
questions.explanation: Luke 17:2 states it would be better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck and he cast into the sea than to offend one of these little ones, emphasizing the severity of causing others to stumble.

questions.question: According to Luke 17:4, how many times in a day should you forgive your brother if he repents after trespassing against you?
questions.correctAnswer: Seven times
questions.explanation: Luke 17:4 instructs believers to forgive their brother seven times in a day if he repents, highlighting the limitless nature of forgiveness in Christian ethics.

questions.question: What analogy does Jesus use in Luke 17:6 to describe the power of faith?
questions.correctAnswer: A grain of mustard seed
questions.explanation: Jesus compares faith to a grain of mustard seed in Luke 17:6, saying even faith that small can command a sycamine tree to be uprooted and obey, illustrating faith’s potential power.

questions.question: In Luke 17:7-10, what is the main lesson Jesus teaches using the example of a servant who serves his master?
options: Servants should expect thanks for their duty
We should consider ourselves unworthy and only doing our duty
Faith is more important than service
questions.correctAnswer: We should consider ourselves unworthy and only doing our duty
questions.explanation: Luke 17:10 teaches that after doing all commanded, believers should say they are unprofitable servants who have only done their duty, emphasizing humility and duty in service.

questions.question: The cleansing of the ten lepers in Luke 17:12-14 foreshadows which major New Testament theme?
questions.correctAnswer: The inclusive nature of salvation
questions.explanation: The healing of ten lepers, including a Samaritan (Luke 17:16), symbolizes inclusion of Gentiles and outcasts into salvation, a key New Testament theme.

questions.question: Which statement best describes Jesus’ response to the Pharisees’ question about the kingdom of God in Luke 17:20-21?
options: The kingdom comes with visible signs
The kingdom is an external political realm
The kingdom is within or among you
The kingdom will come only in the future
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom is within or among you
questions.explanation: Luke 17:21 explains the kingdom of God is not observed externally but is within you, indicating an internal, spiritual reign rather than a political kingdom.

questions.question: The comparison of the days of Noah and the days of Lot in Luke 17:26-29 serves what literary and theological purpose?
options: To illustrate the suddenness and judgment of the Son of Man's coming
To highlight the prosperity of ancient times
To emphasize the importance of marriage
questions.correctAnswer: To illustrate the suddenness and judgment of the Son of Man's coming
questions.explanation: Luke 17:26-29 parallels Noah's and Lot's days to warn about the unexpected and judgmental nature of the Son of Man's return, a typological foreshadowing.

questions.question: In Luke 17:32, Jesus tells his followers to 'Remember Lot's wife.' What is the cultural and theological significance of this reference?
options: She represents disobedience and the danger of longing for the past
She is an example of faithfulness
She illustrates the power of prayer
questions.correctAnswer: She represents disobedience and the danger of longing for the past
questions.explanation: Lot’s wife, who looked back and became a pillar of salt (Genesis 19), symbolizes the peril of attachment to worldly things and disobedience, reinforcing Jesus’ warning in Luke 17:32.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the phrase, 'Whosoever shall seek to save his life shall lose it; and whosoever shall lose his life shall preserve it' in Luke 17:33?
options: Physical life is more important than spiritual
One should avoid risk at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Self-sacrifice leads to true life
questions.explanation: Luke 17:33 teaches a paradoxical principle found throughout Scripture that losing one’s life for Christ’s sake results in eternal preservation, emphasizing self-denial.

questions.question: According to Luke 17:34-36, what will happen to people during the coming judgment day?
options: Some will be taken and others left
All will be gathered together peacefully
questions.correctAnswer: Some will be taken and others left
questions.explanation: Luke 17:34-36 describes a division where one is taken and another left, indicating selective judgment, a theme also found in eschatological teachings elsewhere.

questions.question: In Luke 17:37, Jesus answers 'Where?' regarding those taken and left with what analogy?
options: Where the body is, there the eagles will be gathered
Where the sheep go, the shepherd follows
Where the vine is, there the branches abide
Where the treasure is, there your heart will be
questions.correctAnswer: Where the body is, there the eagles will be gathered
questions.explanation: Jesus uses the imagery of eagles gathering where the body is in Luke 17:37, symbolizing that judgment and gathering will occur at the place of death or consequence.

questions.question: True or False: In Luke 17:15-16, the one leper who returned to give thanks was a Jew.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Luke 17:16 identifies the thankful leper as a Samaritan, highlighting the theme of unexpected gratitude and Gentile inclusion.

questions.question: Which Greek word for 'faith' in Luke 17:5-6 is significant for understanding the mustard seed analogy, and what does it imply?
questions.correctAnswer: Pistis - trust and conviction
questions.explanation: The Greek 'pistis' used here refers to faith as trust and conviction, implying that even a small measure can achieve great power, as in the mustard seed analogy in Luke 17:6.

questions.question: How does the teaching in Luke 17:1-4 about offenses and forgiveness connect with the broader Biblical theme of covenant community?
options: It emphasizes maintaining holiness through forgiveness
It prioritizes ritual cleansing over forgiveness
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes maintaining holiness through forgiveness
questions.explanation: Luke 17:1-4 teaches forgiveness to preserve the community's holiness and unity, reflecting covenantal responsibility found throughout the Old and New Testaments.

questions.question: In the historical context of Luke 17, what was the significance of Jesus instructing the healed lepers to show themselves to the priests (Luke 17:14)?
options: To confirm their cleansing according to Mosaic Law
To enroll in a new religious order
questions.correctAnswer: To confirm their cleansing according to Mosaic Law
questions.explanation: According to Levitical law, priests verified a leper's cleansing before reintegration into society; Jesus instructs this in Luke 17:14, underscoring respect for the law.

theological.title: Luke Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Luke Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Luke 17:1-2, what is the consequence for one who causes offense to 'these little ones'?
options: It is better for him to have a millstone hung about his neck and be cast into the sea
He will receive a crown of righteousness
He will be exalted in the kingdom of God
questions.correctAnswer: It is better for him to have a millstone hung about his neck and be cast into the sea
questions.explanation: Luke 17:2 explicitly states that it would be better for such a person to have a millstone hung around his neck and be cast into the sea, emphasizing the gravity of causing offense to the innocent. This reflects themes in Matthew 18:6 and Mark 9:42 where Jesus warns against causing others to sin.

questions.question: What is the prescribed response when a brother trespasses against you and then repents, according to Luke 17:3-4?
questions.correctAnswer: Forgive him
questions.explanation: Luke 17:3-4 teaches the necessity of forgiveness when a brother repents, even if he sins repeatedly. This aligns with Jesus' teaching on forgiveness in Matthew 18:21-22 and the apostolic emphasis on forgiveness in Ephesians 4:32.

questions.question: In Luke 17:5-6, what analogy does Jesus use to describe the power of even a small amount of faith?
questions.correctAnswer: A grain of mustard seed
questions.explanation: Jesus compares faith to a mustard seed in Luke 17:6, illustrating that even a small measure of true faith can accomplish great things, such as uprooting a sycamine tree. This metaphor is also found in Matthew 17:20 and emphasizes faith's divine potential.

questions.question: According to Luke 17:7-10, how should servants view their obedience to their masters?
options: As simply fulfilling their duty, not expecting thanks
As earning a reward and praise
As optional and based on goodwill
As a burden to be avoided
questions.correctAnswer: As simply fulfilling their duty, not expecting thanks
questions.explanation: Luke 17:7-10 emphasizes that servants do their commanded duties out of obligation and should not expect thanks, paralleling the humility and duty expected of believers in Colossians 3:23-24 and 1 Corinthians 4:1-2.

questions.question: What miracle involving ten men with leprosy is recorded in Luke 17:11-19?
options: They were healed after being told to show themselves to the priests
They were given the Holy Spirit
They were sent away without healing
They were taught the law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: They were healed after being told to show themselves to the priests
questions.explanation: Luke 17:14 recounts Jesus healing ten lepers who were told to present themselves to the priests, which was the prescribed method for being declared clean (Leviticus 14:2-32). This miracle highlights Jesus' messianic authority and fulfills Old Testament purification rites.

questions.question: In Luke 17:15-19, what is significant about the one leper who returned to give thanks?
questions.correctAnswer: He was a Samaritan
questions.explanation: Luke 17:16-18 notes that the thankful leper was a Samaritan, underscoring the theme of gratitude and faith among outsiders, which challenges Jewish exclusivism and aligns with themes in John 4:9 and Acts 8:9-25.

questions.question: How does Jesus describe the coming of the kingdom of God in Luke 17:20-21?
options: It comes not with observation, but is within you
It will be announced with great signs in the sky
It will be established by political power
It will be visible in a specific location on earth
questions.correctAnswer: It comes not with observation, but is within you
questions.explanation: Luke 17:20-21 teaches that the kingdom of God is not a visible, worldly kingdom but an internal spiritual reality, consistent with Jesus' teaching in John 18:36 and Paul's exposition in Romans 14:17.

questions.question: What warning does Jesus give in Luke 17:22-24 regarding the days of the Son of Man?
options: Do not follow false claims about seeing Him before His coming
questions.correctAnswer: Do not follow false claims about seeing Him before His coming
questions.explanation: Luke 17:23 warns against following those who claim the Messiah is here or there, emphasizing vigilance and discernment, similar to warnings in Matthew 24:23-27 and Mark 13:21-23.

questions.question: According to Luke 17:25, what must the Son of Man experience before His final coming?
options: He must suffer many things and be rejected
He must gather a great army
questions.correctAnswer: He must suffer many things and be rejected
questions.explanation: Luke 17:25 states that the Son of Man will first suffer and be rejected by the current generation, affirming the prophetic sufferings foretold in Isaiah 53:3 and fulfilled in the passion narratives (e.g., Mark 8:31).

questions.question: What two Old Testament figures are referenced in Luke 17:26-29 to illustrate the conditions before the Son of Man's revelation?
questions.correctAnswer: Noah and Lot
questions.explanation: Luke 17:26-29 compares the days of the Son of Man to the days of Noah and Lot, highlighting human complacency before divine judgment, consistent with Genesis 6-7 and Genesis 19, teaching eschatological preparedness.

questions.question: What instruction does Jesus give in Luke 17:31 concerning possessions during the day of the Son of Man's coming?
options: Do not go back to retrieve your possessions
Gather all your goods and flee
Hide your possessions in secret places
Sell all your possessions to help the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Do not go back to retrieve your possessions
questions.explanation: Luke 17:31 advises not to return for belongings during the eschatological event, indicating urgency and total commitment, paralleling Matthew 24:17-18 and Luke 9:62's call for undivided loyalty.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of the phrase 'Remember Lot's wife' in Luke 17:32?
options: It warns against looking back with longing for a sinful past
It commands strict observance of the law
It promises material blessings for the faithful
questions.correctAnswer: It warns against looking back with longing for a sinful past
questions.explanation: Luke 17:32 references Lot's wife as a caution to avoid clinging to sinful life as seen in Genesis 19:26, symbolizing the need for decisive faith and obedience in the face of judgment.

questions.question: What paradox does Jesus present about life and death in Luke 17:33?
options: Whoever seeks to save his life will lose it, and whoever loses his life will preserve it
Whoever gains wealth will lose his soul
Whoever judges others will be judged harshly
Whoever loves the world hates God
questions.correctAnswer: Whoever seeks to save his life will lose it, and whoever loses his life will preserve it
questions.explanation: Luke 17:33 presents a paradox of discipleship emphasizing self-denial, consistent with Jesus' teachings in Mark 8:35 and John 12:25 about finding true life through surrender.

questions.question: In Luke 17:34-36, what is described about people during the night of the Son of Man's coming?
options: Two men will be in one bed; one taken, one left
Everyone will gather for a feast
All will repent and be saved
questions.correctAnswer: Two men will be in one bed; one taken, one left
questions.explanation: Luke 17:34-36 describes sudden separation and judgment at the Son of Man's coming, echoing themes of divine election and eschatological division found in Matthew 24:40-41 and 1 Thessalonians 4:17.

questions.question: What imagery does Jesus use in Luke 17:37 to respond to the disciples' question about where the taken ones will be gathered?
options: Wherever the body is, there the eagles will be gathered
As stars falling from the sky
Like wheat and tares in the field
questions.correctAnswer: Wherever the body is, there the eagles will be gathered
questions.explanation: Luke 17:37 uses the metaphor of eagles gathering where the body is, suggesting the inevitability and divine precision of judgment, consistent with prophetic imagery in Ezekiel 39:4 and Revelation 19:17-18.
